div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Egyptian Cotton in India
div.p: In a paper read before the Society of Arts on this subject, Mr. Laurence Robertson, I.C.S., mentioned that in the Jamrao colony in Sind, Egyptian cotton has been successfully acclimatised. The lint, he said, produced has been pronounced to be equal to the best Egyptian product in fineness and length of staple, and has realised very remunerative prices. Last summer an area of 6,000 acres was sown by the moroe enterprising landholders, prominent among whom where the Panjabi settlers, and although just before the harvest the crop was almost completely ruined by the boll-worm what was saved was of fine quality and realised good prices. In the Chenab colony, important work has been done in the acclimatisation of both Egyptian and American cotton. Here again, repeated destructive attacks of boll-worm have prevented absolutely assured results being obtained. The Agricultural Department is very hopeful of devising some effective means of combating this destructive pest, and when this difficulty has been overcome, India will possess a splendid supply of fine long-stapled cotton, which cannot fail to have important effects on her own cotton manufacturing industry, and on that of this country.

In the discussion which followed frequent comparisons of irrigation methods in Egypt and India were made. Colonel Sir Colin Scott-Moncrieff, K.C.S.I., K.C.M.G., referred to a statement made that much depended upon the sympathy of the canal and revenue offiers, and said that when he first went to Egypt he was fortunate enough to get a most valuable party of officers to follow him from India. They were just beginning to speak Arabic after a year's residence in the country, when complaints began to reach him of oppression I the Irrigation Department, and he told the natives that he would send a native commissioner to inquire into them. They instantly replied, "No, no, for goodness sake do not send him ; send one of the new Englishmen." He remembered that on one occasion one of his new "new Englishmen," a very brilliant fellow, was riding through a village and was greeted by the not uncommon cry, "There goes a Christian dog," when one of the natives who knew of his work in the Irrigation Department, said, "No, that man is not a Christian, he is an Englishman." He believed it was that sympathy, apart from his high technical skill, which made the irrigation officer a success. In Indie they soon found out the difference between the man who looked on his work as an end, and on the man who looked upon the work as a means to an end; and it was the latter kind of man that they always tried to select for the chage of the running water, and for settling the little disputes between man and man.

div.head: Spirit Stove Explosion.
div.p: At Abbassia, while preparing a meal, an Austrian woman, named Ameb, was killed by the sudden explosion of a spirit stove.

div.head: Ministry of the Interior.
div.p: Twenty-six European police officers successfully passed in the examination recently held in the Arabic language, class 'A', and three passed class 'B'.

div.head: A Fatal Fall.
div.p: A carpenter's apprentice, named Hassan Essaid, a native boy aged 16, fell from the scaffolding of a house under construction at Old Cairo and was instantly killed.

div.head: New Credits
div.p: At their last meeting the Council of Ministers authorized credits of L E. 10,000 for the cattle plague, and L.E. 12,000 for the construction of a new road at Matarieh.

div.head: Sudan Land
div.p: The Sudan Government has granted the fonds necessary for the increase of staff engaged in the registration of lands in the Blue Nile Province. The newly appointed officials will shortly commence their work.

div.head: Bubonic Plague
div.p: During the past week the following particulars were registered : — 1 recovery at Beba, 2 deaths in hospital at Damanhour and 13 admissions to and 1 death, in hospital at Esneh. 31 patients are still under treatment.

div.head: Municipal Commission.
div.p: The Meeting of the Alexandria Municipal Commission, which was to have taken place yesterday, was postponed owing to the lack of a quorum. The next meeting will in all probability be held on Wednesday next.

div.head: Fire at Cairo.
div.p: On Tuesday, at 1 o'clock, a fire broke out in a grocer's shop, in Bab-el-Charmia, destroying several pounds worth of flour and charcoal. The fire brigade, which was immediately summoned, rapidly extinguished the conflagration.

div.head: Egypt's Land Boom
div.p: The July "Blackwood" will contain an article on the "Egyptian Boom" by Sir Robert Hamilton Lang, formerly British member of the Council of Direction of the Daira Sanieh Administration. Sir Robert visited Egypt during the past season.

div.head: Agricultural Bank.
div.p: Applications have been made to the Stock Exchange Committee to appoint a special settling day in and to grant a quotation to: Agricultural Bank of Egypt. Scrip (fully and partly paid) for a further issue of £1,000,000 Sterling 3 1/2 per Cent. Guaranteed Bonds.

div.head: A Suakin Rumour.
div.p: It is rumored in Suakin that the Turkish Government has issued an order prohibiting all Turkish subjects employed in the service of the Egyptian and the Sudan Governments and who are now within the Turkish provinces from returning to Egypt or the Sudan. On the face of it, the rumor seems absurd.

div.head: Births and Deaths.
div.p: During the week ending 24th instant, 508 births, 9 of which were of European parentage, and 774 deaths, of which 13 were European, were registered in Cairo. 628 of the deaths were children under 5 years of age. The following causes of death are given :—6 of dyptheria, 5 typhus, 1 typhoid, 77 measles, 2 small pox, 5 erysipelas, and 4 of fever.

div.head: Cattle Plague.
div.p: 404 fatal cases of cattle plague were recorded throughout Egypt during the week ending the 24th instant, of which 54 were in the district of Maghaghi, 59 at Beni-Mazar, 30 at Fashn, 35 at Sammallout, 16 at Minia, 17 at Abou-Kerkns, 43 at Manfalout, 71 at Mellawi, 27 at Deirout, 4 at Badari, 7 at Zagazig, 4 at Belbei, 1 at Tanta, 24 at Beba, 4 in the Fayoum, 1 at Etzai, 2 at Helouan, 3 at Timbellawein and 2 at Kaliout.

div.head: The Lambert Case.
div.p: As an example of the amenities of journalism in this country, the following expression of M. Verdier, of "Les Pyramides" in reference to the Lambert affair, deserves to lie cited :— "Avec un merveilleux dédain, M. Lambert a secoué la poussière de ses souliers sur le crâne de M. Dunlop Another contemporary remarks :—"Ce langage nous étonne de M. Verdier. II est beau de prendre en mains les intérêts de son pays, mais les discussions doivent rester courtoises."

div.head: Pelots.
div.p: The interesting series of games of Pelota, which have been regularly given at Alexandria of late by the old Ramleh Terminus, have been suspended for a few days owing to certain improvements rendered necessary in the electric light. The games will begin again daily on Friday evening next at 9.30 o'clock. The betting tickets have been altered and the unit is now P.T. 10. The entrance charges have been also reduced as follows ; boxes, P. T. 20 ; stalls, P.T. 5 ; Gallery, P.T. 2. Every Saturday and Sunday afternoon there will be afternoon performances from 5 to 8 pm.

div.head: SAVOY PALACE HOTEL
div.p: The Administration of the Savoy Palace Hotel at Alexandria requests us to announce that it has decided to close the hotel from June 15 to October 1. [Advt.]

div.head: MINERAL WATERS.
div.p: We remind our readers that Spathis' celerated minerals are the best in Egypt. (Advt.)

div.head: THE CASSA DI SCONTO.
div.p: Although there are many and various rumors as to the line of action which Sir Ernest Cassel intends to pursue in regard to the Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio, nothing has yet been decided on, and we are authorized to state that all such rumours are entirely premature as Sir Ernest has not as yet given any official intimation as to the course of policy he intends to pursue in the matter.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS AND BOURSE
div.p: The Alexandrian branch of the Crédit Lyonnais has made an application to the Mixed Tribunals for the purpose of the nomination by the Court of a "huissier" with the necessary lowers for maintaining an open market for the sale of shares on the Bourse at Alexandria. The reason for this curious demand is that recently the brokers boycotted the forced sale of shares by the bank so effectually that no operation could take place. The tribunal has left the application in suspense. It is considered that no definite reply will be given.

div.head: "LA REFORME"
div.p: Pressure on our space prevents us to day from criticizing the extraordinary and financially unsound proposals which appeared in yesterday's issue of onr contemporary "La Réforme" under the heading of ''La Banque d'Etat et les biens libres" above the well known initials R.C.
We propose, however, in a future issue to consider this article.

div.head: E.S.R. LAND AND ESTATE OFFICE.
div.p: A large amount of work has been done by this branch of the Egyptian Government Railways, and in spite of numerous difficulties and delays good progress has been made. The work of surveying and marking the boundaries of the railway has been carried out on 335 kilometres of line, and surveys have been made of eleven stations for the same purpose. Flans and information have had to be provided for 43 law suits completed during the year, and for 53 cases in which the Administration had to take legal action, and plans and information have been supplied in order to defend 34 actions taken against the Administration. 168 eases of encroachment have been dealt with, 32 of which involved legal proceedings. Land purchase to the value of LE. 65,074 has been completed, the greater portion of this expenditure being made on account of increased accommodation required at Cairo Station.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES LINE.
div.p: It will be remembered that lost July, the State Railways look over the standard gauge lines of the Société Générale des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte, including all sidings loading platforms, turn-tables and all strips of laud adjoining the permanent wav, as well as the workshops at Minieh, sheds at Biheh and Magaga and the locomotive shed at Motana, together with all the rolling stock, machinery, fools, etc.

Now steps are being taken to put the system into working order and it is proposed to inaugurate a passenger service on the northern section and to construct a telephone line so that trains can be worked on the staff and ticket system. Facilities will also be given to the public for the transmission of messages in the form of telegrams over these circuits.

Owing to the sugar cane season for 1906 being over before the lines were transferred to the State Railways, it is not possible to give an estimate as to what the yearly receipts are likely to amount to, hut it is hoped that in course of time they will more than cover the expenses

The length of the lines taken over amounted to 595 kiloms., of which 63 kiloms. are in the southern section on the western side of the River from Dabayeh to Erment and Motana factories. The northern section is also on the western side of tho river from Beni-Suef to Magaga, Minieh, Abou-Kirkas, and Rhodah and amounts to 532 kilometres.
The lines are laid partly on wooden sleepers and partly on saddle back sleepers. About one-third of the whole system was in good order when taken over.
The rolling stock consists of 67 locomotives, 1942 sugar trucks and 359 refuse tracks.

div.head: THE NATIVE COURT OF APPEAL. SIR E. GREY's SHARP RETORT.
div.p: The following questions, summarized in our cable on the 19th, were asked in the House of Commons on Tuesday week :

Mr. MacNeill asked the Secretary for Foreign Affairs whether the Procureur Général, Mr. E. K. Corbet, C.M.G., Messrs. J. L. Willmore, and V. S. Alston, judges of the Native Court of Appeal in Egypt, were originally appointed by the Egyptian Government without having had any previous legal training whatsoever.

Sir E. Grey : I do not know what the legal training was in all these cases. I have no doubt that the qualifications were considered when the appointments were made, and i am not aware of any reason whatever for interfering with them.
Mr. MacNeill : Is not the right hon. gentleman well aware that these gentlemen know nothing whatever of the law, and that this is a Punch-and-Judy tribunal ! (Laughter.)
Sir E. Grey : The information I have with regard to one of these judges is that he is fully qualified, (Cheers.)
Mr. MacNeill : Who is he ?
Sir E. Grey : I specially referred to Mr. Willmore. hut with regard to all the appointments I have no reason to siqqiose that they are not qualified.
Mr. Mac Neill : Will the right hon gentleman take the trouble to inquire I
Sir E. Grey : No, sir—(Ministerial cheers)— because I have no reason to suppose there is any occasion for making inquiry.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET. KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT
div.p: There is no improvement in the demand for Spot Egyptians, which continue to be neglected without change in quotations. Only a small business has been done also in Egyptian Futures, and the following are the latest quotations :—

American Futures. The Market this week has been much calmer in tone, and although there have frequent fluctuations they have been much narrower and more the result of professional trailing than of fresh outside interest in the article. To-day's closing values are only 1/2 point decline for the current month, 2 1/2 for June/July and July/August, 4 1/2 for August September, and 7 @ 10 1/2 points for the various New Crop positions from those of last Thursday. Tho continuance of much more favorable weather conditions has checked the speculative feeling and led to a fair amount of liquidation. At present the general opinion as to the future course of the Market is very much divided ; any recurrence of unfavorable Crop conditions would probably produce another sharp rise, hut otherwise present values arc considered high enough, or too high, and if the news continues favorable a further decline would seem probable. The latest values are delivery :—

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner "Tabor" arrived at Liverpool yesterday morning.
The S.S. "Egyptian," of the Westcott and Laurence line, left Malta yesterday and is due here next Sunday with general cargo from Antwerp and London.

div.head: THE YEMEN SITUATION. PEACE COMMISION LEAVES. GENERAL FAIZI'S DIFFICULTIES.
div.p: The Peace Commission has already left Yemen for Constantinople after a fruitless visit which lasted about 2 months, and was taken up for the most part in making tours to Turkish districts. They have taken to Constantinople about 130 native representatives in all, from the principal Turkish districts such as Faéz, Hurraz, Manakha, Sana and Hodeida and other Turkish places. These representations are from those who are apparently loyal Turkish subjects. It is problematical whether any good will result from this course of action, since the Imam has declined to confer with, or to interview, the mission.

On the other hand, all that I have been informed is that since the departure of the mission the Imam has openly taken up the offensive, hut no decisive battle has yet been reported. Faizi Pasha has been for some time asking for fresh reinforcements from Constantinople and showing the necessity for them. He has already requisitioned the garrisons at Zabeed and Mokla and other places, and about eight battalions have been sent to him.
There is no denying the fact that the rebels have now grown more formidable than ever, and what with the lack of funds and soldier's arrears of pay the situation is getting very critical.

The seven battalions of Turkish troops, which according to the gossip of Cairo, was said to have been lost by the Turks in a recent battle with the rebels seems to have no foundation. But I would not be far out if I place this number as the loss suffered by the Turks in the latest two encounters described in previous letters.

div.head: SIR BENJAMIN BAKER'S REQUESTS
div.p: Sir Benjamin Baker, K.C.B., whose estate, as we have already announced, has been sworn at £170,513, with net personalty £166,513, left £2000 to the Benevolent Fluid of the Institution of Civil Engineers, £2000 to the Westminster Hospital £1000 to King Edward's Hospital Fund for London, £500 to the Royal Berks County Hospital, Reading, £500 for the poor of Pangbourne, a perpetual annuity of £12 for the benefit of the poor Ibury, Oxon.

Probate of his will has been granted to his sister, Mrs. Fanny Maria Kent (widow), his niece, Mrs. Kathleen Mona Spagnoletti, wife of Mr. James Ernest Spagnoletti, and Mr. James Ernest Spagnoletti, all of Bowden Green.

div.head: CYPRUS AS A RESORT FOR EGYPTIANS
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Tir,—I was glad to see that in your interesting articles on the attractions of Cyprus yon drew attention to the fact that there were regular sailings under the British flag from Alexandria to that charming island. As a symptom of the prevailing ignorance on this matter I enclosed cutting from a recent contribution from the Cairo correspondent of the "Pall Mall Gazette" :—

"For those who cannot go on leave there is very little distraction in the shape of a change of air. There is no seaside resort to go to for a week end or holiday. Egypt possesses no place giving respite from the ardours of the climate, such as is obtained in India from a sojourn in the hills. Some folk make a trip to Cyprus or the island of Rhodos, but these excursions are not popular, owing to the uncertainty of a sailing back to Alexandria or Port Said, coupled with the possibility of surprises in the shape of quarantine, which are from time to time sprang on one. Were it not for these drawbacks, the inhabitants of Egypt would flock to Cyprus, Rhodos, and the other islets, for the air is wonderfully bracing, and the life and scenery delightful."
I am, Sir
Truly Yours
A Lover of Cyprus.

div.head: EGYPTOLOGY AT THE ROYAL SOCIETY
div.p: There was a distinguished gathering at Burlington House on Wednesday week for the ladies' conversazione of the Royal Society, the guests being received by lord and Lady Raleigh. In the meeting room Professor Flinders Petrie gave an interesting loot re. illustrated by lantern slides, on houses in ancient Egypt, and showed some small pottery models of houses made by the Egyptians, and recently found at Rifeh. In addition to a representative gathering of scientists, the company included the Lord Chancellor, Lord Justice Buckley, Mr. Justice Kennedy, Lord Justice Moulton, the Right Hon. Arthur Balfour and Miss Balfour, the Duke of Northumberland, Lady Wantage, Lady Jane Lindsay, lord and lady Kelvin, lord Avebury, Sir William and lady Huggins, the Earl of Berkeley, Admiral Sir Henny Jackson, and many notabilities in politics, art, and literature.

div.head: THE MEDITERRANEAN FLEET. VISIT TO ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The following is an amended list of the ship* of the Mediterranean Fleet which are due to arrive at Alexandria on the 28th inst., remaining until the 3rd prox. :—
"Queen".—Admiral Sir Charles C. Drury, G C.V.O., K.C.B., K.C.S.L ; Captain Ernest C.T. Troubridge, C.M.G., M.V.O.
"Venerable".—Vice Admiral H.S.H. Prince Louis of Battenberg, G. C. B., G. C. V. 0., K.C.M.G. ; Captain Herbert W. Savory, M.V.O.
"Irresistible".—Captain Hugh P. Williams.
"Prince of Wales"—Captain William B. Fawckner.
"Suffolk".— Captain Rosslyn E. Wemyss, M.V.O.
'Lancaster".— Capt. Herbert L. Heath, M.V.O.
"Barham".—Commander Murray F. Sueter.
Our Naval and Military Correspondent writes from London :—

Arrangements have been made for the embarking of a number of non-commissioned officers and men of the Royal Garrison Artillery at Mediterranean Stations aboard various battleships of the Mediterranean Fleet during the following summer cruise.

When the Mediterranean Fleet leaves Alexandria on the 3rd July it will proceed to Jaffa, where it will remain until the 9th and will afterwards visit Beyrout from (July 10 to 15, Limassol July 16 to 22, Rhodes July 23 to 24, Marmorice July 24 to August 2, and Smyrna August 3 to 12.

div.head: BULLTEIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujoud'hui a 11 h 1/2)

Le marché a ouvert ce matin en pleine effervescence et les cours ont haussé rapidement dans de fortes proportions ; peu à peu, cependant, cette animation s'est calmée pour faire place à one légère réaction. On n'en clôture pas moins A un niveau généralement supérieur à celui d'hier. Comme affaires la séance n été certes la plus brillante que noua ayons eu depuis longtemps, ce qui ne vent pas lire que les transactions aient été énorme», mais qu'elles ont délaissé de beaucoup en nombre et eu importance les misérables séances de ces temps derniers. Beaucoup attribuent la reprise actuelle, lion pas seulement aux achat* de Londres et de Paris niais aussi à l'égorge-, ment d'un découvert qu'on dit assez important.
Les échanges ont porté principalement sur l'Agricole, la National Bank, la Delta Land, les Estates, le Comptoir, l'United, les Ritz et le Crédit Franco-Egyptien.

On a beaucoup parlé de la Cassa di Sconto, sans pour cela traiter d'affaires, du moins à hante voix. Les prix inscrits en clôture sont de 56 l'ancienne action et 64 la nouvelle, en perte respective de 2 et 7 francs. Inutile d'ajouter que cette baisse est aussi nominale que la hausse de ces jours derniers.
En dépit des rumeurs pessimistes répandues sur le compte de la Banque d'Athènes, le cours le cette valeur se maintient à 117, hier 118 ; ce qui est un hon signe.
L'Agricole s'avance de 7 31 32 à 8 3/16, et la National Bank do 19 5/8 à 20. La Delta Light bénéficie pareillement de 18 à 9 1/4, ainsi que la Daïra à 13 3/4.

En hausse également la Béhéra de 27 à 27 1/2, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier de 313 l'an cienne et 264 la nouvelle à 314 et 265 respectivement, les Nungovich Hotels de 15 à 16, la land Bank de 7 1/8 à 7 5/16, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 4 1/4 à 4 1 2, la Building laud, de 2 5/8 5 2 7/8.
Par contre, la Khédivial Mail revient de 4 1/4 à 4 1/8, l'Urbaine de 4 1/16 à 4, et l'Union Foncière de 4 7/8 à 4 1/2.
Beaucoup d'affaires en Delta Land qui bénéficie do 1/4 à 2-2 1/16.
Taudis que l'action Comptoir fléchit de 3 7 16 l'ancienne et 3 1/4 la nouvelle à 3 1/4 et 3 1 /8 respectivement, sa part de fondateur s'avance de 2 1/2 à 3 1/2.

Parmi les petites valeurs, las Ritz gagnent 1/8 à 13 16, l'Helonan 1/16 à 7/16 et la Sait & Soda 9 pence ù 17/9, pendant que l'United perd 1/16 a 7/16, ainsi que les Estates à 7/8, et l'Ordinary Khédivial Mail 1 shelling à 22 6.
Le teste de la cote demeure sans change ment.

En présence des affirmations contradictoires las haussiers et des balisiers il est bien difficile lo pronostiquer l'avenir. Cependant, la hausse persistante des marchés de Londres et de Paris semblent confirmer l'existence sur ces places île groupes acheteurs puissants ; à moins que, comme d'autres le prétendent, la hausse actuelle soit causée surtout par les rachats des baissiers même qui, redoutant un revirement favorable de la situation générale à l'approche de la liquidation, se hâtent de se couvrir avant cette data.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S GRANT. FREEDOM OF CITY
div.p: The Government will propose in both House» a grant of £50,000 to Lord Cromer in appreciation of the great services which he has rendered to Egypt.
His Lordship's health is improving, hut the date of the presentation of the great honour of the freedom of the City of London has not yet been fixed.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARCHAEOLOGY. APPEAL FOR BRITISH SCHOOL.
div.p: An important appeal appears in the Pro on behalf of the British School of Archaeology in Egypt for assistance in the execution of the work at Memphis.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord Edward Cecil has arriver in Cairo on his return from England.

Sir Malcolm McIlwraith is leaving for Athens today to confer with the Greek Government for the appointment of a judge to the Reorm Tribunals. The Judicial Adviser will afterwards continue his voyage to England. During his absence he will be replaced as Advider by Mr. Brunyate.
During the absense of Mr. Gould, Mr. E. A. Grieg will act as Consul at Alexandria.
The Earl of Lanesborough returns to Egypt early next month.

Earl Granville, formerly of the British Agency, Cairo, Second Secretary at the British Embassy at Berlin, has gone home for some time on leave of absence. Lord Granville should certainly have a successful career befor him in the diplomatic world. The son of the famous Victorian statesman and diplomatist, he has inherited much of his father's tact and ability. He has also another link with diplomacy, for he married a few years ago to the daughter of Mr. Walter Barind, Lord Cromer's niece. He was associated with Lord Cromer at Cairo and it was there that he met his wife, who was temporarilt keeping house for her uncle.
Mr. Dunlop has left for England and is replaced as Adviser to the Ministry of Education b Mr. Boyd Carpenter until his return in autumn.

Mr. Webb, under Secretary of State for Irrigation is going on leavea bout the middle of enxt month and will be replaced by Mr. Williams, Inspector General of Lower Egypt, until the 15th August, on which date the latter's leave commences, and after which both functions will be fulfilled by Mr. Dupuis, who has already returned from leave.
Mr. Perry is leaving for England on Saturday on holiday.
During the absense of Mr. Koziebrodsky, Dr. Wagner, Secretary to the Agency, will act as AustroHungarian Diplomatic Agent and Consul General.
Mr. Carter Wilson is expected to reutrn on Monday next. On his arrival, Mr. Machell, the Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior, will go on leave.
We regret to announce the death of the father of Naouam Bey Shoukair, which ccured last week at Beyrout. The deceased was 75 years of age.
Bimbashi J. R. Bassett, 12th Sudanese, has transferred to the Sudan Government.
Mr. Ferguson, bandmaster of the 1st Dragoon Guards, has written to the Press intimating that he has not been appointer Musical Director of the Khedive's army.

Mr. William N. Toulmin, 2, Walpolegardens' Twichenham, a director of the Central Egypt Exploration Company, Limited, the Fatira Exploring Compant, Limited, the Umtali Exploration Company, Limited, etc., died in April, left 2,817 pouns in the United Kingdom.
A marriage has been arranged between Mr. Constant Gasparian and Mrs. Anna Bardishain, daughter of the late Mr. Nerse's Bardisbanian and Mrs. Bardisbanian, nee Sevasly.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny. Notes Et Critiques.
div.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres, qui se maintenait fermement h 4 %, a fini hier par fléchir de 1/8 à 3 7/8 pour cent, signe que le resserrement monétaire commence à se détendre.

Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a avancé de 1/8 à 84 1/2. L'Unifiée est restée invariée à 100 1/4. La National Bank a encore haussé de 3/4 de livre à 19 3/4, l'Agricole de 1/8 à 7 7/8, la Daira Sanieh de 1/2 a 13 3/4 et la Delta Light de 1/4 à 9 3/8.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a gagné 4 francs è 682. La Banque d'Athènes a perdu 2 francs à 114.

Grâce à la hausse persistante des valeurs égyptiennes à Londres et à Paris, notre marché a montré, ce matin encore, d'excellentes dispositions. Les transactions n'ont pas été, il est vrai, considérables, mais leur volume tend visiblement à s'accroître de jour en jour. Au début, l'animation a été vive, mais elle s'est calmée dans le cours de la séance. Apparemment, ceux qui ont du disponible sont toujours hésitants, soit parce qu'ils doivent l'employer pour couvrir, las pertes occasionnées par leurs mécomptes de spéculation, soit parce que, ne croyant pas encore à la stabilité de la reprise, ils entrevoient la possibilité d'acheter, au plus fort de la morte saison, à des prix plus bas. 11 n'en prendront pas moins position lorsque la situation se sera éclaircie, préférant payer plus cher pour éviter les risques du moment. Pour l'instant, tous les regards sont fixés sur Londres, d'où nous viendra la lumière. Aussi attendra-t-on anxieusement, pendant quelques; jours encore, les cours du Stock Exchange, qui constituent actuellement le seul point de repère sérieux.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National a été poussée plus haut qu'à Londres, soit à 19 1/2, pour clôturer à 19 5/16-3/8. L'A-grioole a avancé à 7 7/8-15/16. La Cassa di Sconto a été cotée 50 nominal ; il y avait acheteurs à 40 et vendeurs à 60.

Le Crédit Foncier est remonté à 680 et la Daira à 13 1/2. L'Union Foncière a été ramenée à 4 9/16. Les Allotments ont progressé à 2 1/4 et leur part & 67. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont fléchi à 178, les Ciments à 33 et les fondateurs Héliopolis à 9 1/4.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich, délaissés, ont faibli à 15. Les Egyptian ont avancé à 4 13/16-7/8 et les Excelsior à 2 3/4.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont progressé à 1 11/16. Les Estates sont restés 5 0 13/16-7/8 ; leur part est remontée à 5. Les Walker and Meimarachi ont été quelque peu mieux tenus à 0 5/16, les Khédivial
Mail i 22 sh. et les New Egyptian à 14 sh. 9.
Nous détachons do notre correspondance d'Alexandrie le passage suivant :

" Les rameurs optimistes propagées ces jours-ci relativement à un projet de reconstitution de la Cassa di Sconto patronné par Sir Ernest Cassel et à la formation par le riche financier d'un groupe appelé A relever les valeurs égyptiennes, attendent toujours leur confirmation. En général, ces informations ne sont encore acceptées que sous bénéfice d'inventaire

" La hausse qui vient de se produire à Londres sur les titres égyptiens est plutôt attribuée, non sans raison, aux rachats du découvert à l'approche de la liquidation de fin de mois. Ce découvert était considérable, sur In National Bank principalement, qui était, on s'en souvient, à 23 dans les premiers jours de Juin et que de fortes ventes à découvert ont ramenée jusqu'à 16. Il est tout naturel que las vendeurs appréhendant une solution satisfaisante quelconque de la crise égyptienne, se couvrent à qui mieux mieux pour ne pas perdre une bonne partie de leurs gros bénéfices. On s'attend, d'ailleurs, à ce que les baissiers recommencent ce jeu profitable après la liquidation, si les circonstances leur redeviennent favorables.

"Pour ce qui est de la Cassa di Sconto, la seule nouvelle positive, communiquée officieusement aux journaux, est que " le conseil d'administration d'une part et MM. Russell, Kerr & Wyatt, d'autre part, travaillent A établir la situation complète de l'affaire à ce jour ;mème au prix d'un travail de nuit, on aura terminé ce matin, mercredi 26 Juin, de façon à pouvoir communiquer dé suite le résultat de cet examen aux représentants de sir Ernest Cassel
et aux Banques dont le concours est assuré. "
Le " Journal Officiel " d'avant-hier a publié le décret khédivial autorisant la NationalBank of Egypt A porter son capital à £ 3,500,000.
En conséquence, le capital social est augmenté de £ 500,000, divisées en 50,000 actions nouvelles de £ 10 chacune, que la Banque est autorisée A émettre
Parlant de l'état du marché financier égyptien et des divers projets mis en avant en vue d'améliorer la situation, la " Cote Hebdomadaire " d'Anvers fait les observations ci après :

"La formation d'un syndicat d'acheteurs put avoir pour effet une hausse plus ou moins factice ; certaines affinités peuvent faire que les préférences de la direction du syndicat se porteront plutôt sur telle valeur que sur telle autre, favorisant celle-là et négligeant celle-ci. Enfin, an syndicat acheteur se transforme forcément en syndicat vendeur. La réalisation de gros paquets de titres, même effectuée avec prudence, se reconnaîtra à certains indices ou symptômes et peut alourdir le marché ou provoquer, par le jeu des haussiers et des baissiers, des mouvements en sens divers nuisibles A la stabilité un marché dé jà suffisamment é prouvé.

"Aussi bien il importe de le mettre pour l'avenir à l'abri de secousses aussi profondes qui n'ont pour cause qu'un excès de spéculation mal retenu par des règlements de Bourse qui ne sont plus en rapport avec l'importance des transactions. Pour l'avenir, il ne s'agit pas de prendre "in extremis'' des mesures d'exception d'une application en fait impossibles et nulles comme résultat ; il convient do réorganiser les Bourses d'Alexandrie et du Caire sur des bases mieux appropriées à leur importance actuelle"

div.head: THE NILE VALLEY COMPANY, LD.
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN, in pursuance of Section 142 of the Companies' Act 1862, that a General Meeting of the Members of the above named Company will be held at Winchester House, Old Broad Street, London, EC., on Thursday, the 25th day of July, 1907, at 11:30 o'clock in the forenoon precisely, for the purpose of having an account laid before them showing the manner in which the winding up has been conducted, and the property of the Company disposed of, and of hearing any explanation that may be given by the Liquidator, and also of determining by Extraordinary Resolution, the remuneration of the Liquidator, and the manner in which the books, accounts and documents of the Company, and of the Liquidator, shall be disposed of.
Dated this 14th day of June, 1907.
Joseph Pasfield,
Liquidator.

div.head: MAISON T.A. SPARTALI & CO.
div.p: La maison T.A. Spartali & Co., si connue et appréciée pour l'incomparable choix de tapis d'Orient qu'elle offre aux connaisseurs, a eu '.'excellente idée d'ouvrir une succursale à San Stefano, près le Casino.

C'est une heureuse inspiration. San Stefano, eu cette saison, est le rendez vous de la Société élégante d'Alexandrie et du Caire. Une exposition de tapis, aux portes du Casino de San Stefano, ne peut manquer «l'attirer et retenir l'attention des amateurs de jolies choses, car on sait que la collection de tapis T.A. Spartali comporte de véritables oeuvres d'art, pièces incomparables, mises en vente A des prix très modérés."

div.head: The Corporation of Western Egypt, Ltd.
div.p: NOTICE is hereby given that on and after the 30th June 1907, interest at the rate of Five per cent will be charged on all unpaid calls from the due date thereof until the date of payment.
By order of the Board.
W. C. Scales.
Local Secretary.

div.head: HOUSE OF COMMONS. Voting on the Lords.

div.p: House of Commons. The debate on the Lords' resolution was resumed. A Labourite and Nationalist amendment urged the complete abolition of the House of Lords. Mr. Winston Churchill advised the opposition to treat the resolution seriously. He said the Government repudiated th claim that the Lords had known better than the people themselves what the people wanted. The House of Lords was not a nationalist institution but a party dodge. Its veto had been used for the grossest and basest purposes of unscrupulous political dishonesty. The disussion has been adjourned. (Reuter)
Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman's resolution with reference to the Lords was adopted by 432 votes to 147, after the rejection of the Labourite amendment by 315 votes to 100. (Reuter)

div.head: BOMB THROWING IN TIFLIS. Thieft From Postal Van.

div.p: Ten bombs have been thrown succesively in Erivan Square in the centre of the town, which was crowded with people at the time. They exploded with appalling force. Many have been killed or injured. Immense damage has been done over a large area.

(Later). The object of the bomb throwers was to seize 25,000 pounds which was being escorted from the Post Office to the Bank. The whole sum was stolen, amidst the panic due to the bursting bombs. The number of fatalities is uncertain. (Reuter)
Ten bombs thrown into the square of Erivan have killed many persons and covered the theft of 341,000 roubles from a postal van. (Havas)

div.head: THE SPANISH AGREEMENT. An Extended Scope.

div.p: It is pointed out that the Spanish agreements have a wider scope that was supposed. They guarantee apparently the status-quo of the whole of the Mediterranean and Atlantic washing the shores of Europe and Africa. (R.)

It is understood that the Government will shortly propose a grant of 50,000 pounds for Lord Cromer. The delay in making the announcement is due to the state of his Lordship's health, which is now practitcally restored. (R.)
Sir E. Grey stated that the Government had decided to make a special grant to Lord Cromer. (Reuter)
The Army Bill has passed the second reading and has been voted unanimously. (Havas)
The Senate has adopted the law discharging the 1903 class. (Havas)
M. Albert has surrendered in Montpellier. (Reuter)
M. Albert has surrendered himself as prisoner. (Havas)
The Khedive has passed. He was greeted by a salute of guns. (Havas)
The cruiser "Inflexible" has been launched at Clyde Bank. (Reuter)
A huge fire has destroyed the entrepôt of the Victoria Omnibus Company. (Havas)
The Commission of the Chamber of Deputies propose to send the ex-Minister Nasi before the High Court. (Havas)
Yorkshire beat Somerset by an innings and 45 runs. Cambridge University beat M.C.C. by 8 wickets. The South Africans beat Kent by 2 runs. The other matches have been drawn. (Reuter)

div.head: The Money Market.
div.p: The continued liquidation in Cairo and Alexandria naturally led to the feeling here that ere long further heavy .shipments of gold to Egypt would become necessary, hut mi far happily these fears have proved groundless, and it is now hoped that the time of stress will be tided over without this assistance.

A slight hardening of rates yesterday follow e*l the payment of calls of the Japanese and LC.C. loans, and call loans fetched as much as per cent. Relief came in the afternoon, however, as the result of the release of the funds, and 3 per cent, became the general rate. Weekly accommodation was also obtainable at this figure, and two and three mouths' hills fetched 3 per cent.
The India Council renewed a .small amount for three weeks at 3 per cent.
There has been no demand for Franco this week, and nearly the whole of the arrivals amounting to about £500,000, was purchased by the Bank of England.

Thanks to the return of currency from the country, the Bank return this week shows an in crease in the reserve of £680,000, at £25,298,000. There is an increase of £1,061,305 in Public Deposits and the discounting of bills by the market at the Bank has caused a rise of £408,577 in other securities. The stock of bullion is higher by £661,000, and the note circulation shows a contraction of £15,000. The ratio of reserve to liabilities is up J at 47jJ per cent.
The price of bar gold has to-day recoiled 1/8 to 77s 9d.

div.head: Silver.
div.p: There has been a good undertone in tho silver market, and prices have moved upwards. The quotation for bar silver is 1/8 higher at 30, 15/16.

div.head: The Stock Markets.
div.p: As will be seen by our report on the Egyptian share market, the past week has been characterized by a further considerable depreciation in Egyptian securities and the weak ness of this section has again been an important factor in the movements of other markets. It is a long lane that has no turning, however, and the feeling is growing here that the fierce burst of liquidation has now almost spent its force. Shares have been pushed down from their former inflated levels to a point whore they become good lock-up investments, and the shrewder brokers, King fully alive to this and the fact that a considérable rise in prices must inevitably follow when things assume a more normal appearance, have this week continued the policy of quietly absorbing the better class stocks.

Markets generally are very flat, and there is almost entire absence of business. In the present state of nervousness idle rumours, which in more healthy periods are laughed to scorn, are able to exercise a forcible influence, and this is likely to continue until investors willing to give the support which is so much needed.

div.head: Consols.
div.p: New records in depression have been created by Consols this week, the quotation having at one time gone below 83 for the account. This attributed to a report that the impending Transvaal loan will bear interest at 3 per cent, and will be issued in the neighbourhood of par. The Bank came in a heavy buyer of the stock, but without appreciable effect upon the market
Yesterday the tone was firmer, and business was done at 83, 9/16 for cash and account The last quotations, however, were only 1/16 higher on the day at 83 for money and 83 for the account.
Today consols close with a further advance of 1/16.

div.head: Foreign Bonds.
div.p: The international section commenced the week anything but cheerfully, the announcement of the dissolution of the second Duma causing much anxiety. Russian bonds dropped point, but later in the day, when it was found that Paris had taken the dissolution calmly, the tendency became more confident, and prices closed slightly above Saturday's levels.
The bonds have kept firm for the greater part of the week, although the Fives eased off somewhat yesterday.
To-day Russians have been heavy. The Fives have fallen 3/8 to 81 1/8, and the Fours 1/4 to 73 1/4.
At the beginning of the week Japanese stocks were firm at advances of 1/4, but have since moved downwards, the Fours losing 3/8, to 86 7/8, yesterday.
Japanese have further receded today.

div.head: Home Rails.
div.p: The anticipation that the demand of the railway employé for higher wages and shorter hours of labour will before long take a more definite form is exercising a weakening effect on this market, investors being unwilling to give support in the present uncertain state of affairs.

A very unsatisfactory feature has been the decline in prior charge stocks. Yesterday District Extension Preference dropped 61 to 30, and there were several declines of a full point In the ordinary shares there was little business done, with the exception of a few purchases of North Western and the Deferred stocks of the Southern lines.
Home Rails have been weak today, at declines of 1/4 to 1/2.

div.head: Americans.
div.p: The American railway market has passed an uneventful week, and business has been on a limited scale. The tone has been good, however. Union Pacific have been the most active feature. On Wednesday these came over from New York at 134 7/8, and opened at 135£. In the early afternoon they were taken to 135], hut reacted to 134 1/4, subsequently recovering in the Street to 135 3/4. Yesterday these shares received considerable support from New York, the price advancing to 136 1/8. Aitchison, Baltimore and Ohio, and Northern Pacific were also firm at an advance of a point, while Southern Pacific and Reading gained 3/4. Illinois Central shed 1.
Movements in Americans to-day have generally been adverse. Unions have given way 1 1/2 and South Pacifies 1 3/8.

div.head: Egyptians.
div.p: We have had another week of falling prices and there seems further liquidation going on on your side. Thousands of shares have changed hands practically without any regard to price, and the remarkable thing is that it has not ended in a panic. Fortunately, however, all the shares that are pressed for sale are well taken, the best houses thus showing their confidence in their ultimate value.

For the present the market is in a Lui enough state, the weakness being accentuated by a number of rumours, the majority of which are quite discredited by sensible people. They are, however, sufficient to upset holders in nervous times like these.

National Bank have fallen today 16 1/2 - 3/4, and Agricultural Bank to 7 1/8 - 3/8. The latter are much the best market, and on the whole have been fairly firm. Agricultural Preference are 9 1/4. Delta Preference Bearer have been very flat, and were dealt in yesterday as low as 8 3/4. They leave off today at 8 1/2 - 9. Delta Land & Investment are 1 5/8 - 7/8.

Egyptian Estates seem cheap at their present price of 13/16-15/16. Daira Sanieh are down to 12-13, and the Deferred to 70. Salt & Soda have changed hands at 19/-s., but Egyptian Markets have not been mentioned and close 1 1/8 - 1/4. Union Foncière are quoted 4 1/4 - 1/2, and Land Bank of Egypt 6 1/4 - 3/4. New Egyptian are also very dull at 11/16-13/16, and Land & General Trust have been offered at 15/32. Khédivial Mail are supposed to be 1 - 1/4. There is not a single quotation for Comptoir Financier, and they were last mentioned on the basis of 3 - 1/2.

div.head: Mining.
div.p: The Rand dividends announced this week are on the whole very satisfactory. The most

unfavorable feature is the passing of the Premier dividend, although in some quarters this was expected. The directors say that they could have distributed 400 per cent to the Deferred shareholders, hut they deemed policy of caution to he best, their desire King to strengthen the financial position of tho company. By some people this is interpreted to mean further large expenditure on machinery Rand Mines again pay 60 per cent. (3/-s. per share); Rose Deep 12} % (2/6 per share) as compared with 2/-a. previously ; Ferriera 150% (30/-S. per share, as before) ; Robinson Deep 374% (7/6 per share, against 8/-a); Modderfontein 3/-a, as compared with 4/-a; Robinson 10/-S. against 11/-s; Crown Deep 50% (10/-s.) against 40 %; Geldenhuis Deep 15% (3/-s per share, as against 4/-s.) ; and Van Ryn 20%, making, with the 10% distributed in January, 30% for the year.
The publication of these results had a good effect upon the market, and even Premiers registered an advance of about ] to 10. Modders were a feature and gained 3/8 to 5 1/4.
French selling in connection with the settlement caused a setback yesterday, and De Beers lost 11/16 to 23, 5/16, Premier 5/16, and Vaal River 3/8.
The market lias been flat again today Premier and De Beers are 1/4 lower and Rand Mines have dropped 3/16 to 5 5/16.
Egyptian mining shares are flat. Egyptian Mines Exploration are back to 1/3 and Nile Valleys are unaltered at 1/-.
The closing prices to-night are as follows:

div.head: ISLAM. "The Crescent and The Cross"
div.p: When Mr. Halil Halid, the author of this suggestive book, was contemplating its publication, he was advised by an English friend to withhold his name from the title-page, for fear that an English audience might resent so plain-spoken an utterance. Mr. Halid, however, thought better of our toleration, ami he was unquestionably right "Thought is free"; every man is entitled to the virtue of patriotism, ami no right-thinking man could possibly resent Mr. Halid's confidence in his own country and own faith, even if it does sometimes run counter to our own predilections.

There is no antagonism, he assures us, among the followers of Islam towards fundamental Christianity. The Mohammedans speak of Christ as "the Spirit of God" and, though they cannot accept the story of the crucifixion, holding it to inflict a degradation inconceivable loan emanation of the Deity, they have always reverenced the Holy Land, and respected the sanctity of the Holy Sepulchre. But Islam, while paying all honour to the founder of Christianity, is unable to reconcile itself to the priesthood which lias proclaimed His message. Mahomet disliked a priesthood as tending to trickery and sorcery, ami it is also felt in the East that the often-repeated boast that "the flag follows the Cross" has been over and over again a confession that bloodshed and cruelty have attended the preaching of a gospel of peace and goodwill.

"It is quite certain," says Mr. Halid, "that Islam will not readily avail itself of baptism. If Islam dies out in the long run Christianity will not outlive it". Mr. Halid speaks quite frankly but with all decent reticence of those parts of the Christian service which strike a Mussulman as anamalous. Foremost among these is the offertory, which to a devout follower of Islam seems like a profanation of the sanctuary—an unpardonable intrusion upon tho devout offices of praise and prayer. Mr. Halid further defends the position of Moslem women, ami the institution of polygamy, maintaining that women are protected with peculiar chivalry, ami that the legitimacy of offspring is commonly secured by plurality of wives. Finally he speaks emphatically concerning the menace to the peace of the Orient which the Mussulman dreads from the advance of Western Empire. "Mussulmans," he says, "must not allow themselves to be reduced to the same situation as that in which the entire Jewish people were placed centuries ago. There is room for all desirable strangers in this hospitable continent of Asia, but empire-making' by outsiders must lie henceforth forbidden."

It is well to see imperial problems through other eyes, and the moderation and critical force of Mr. Halid's book demands respect and consideration. No one can read it without being brought into closer relation with the standpoint of the East.

The following is the result of yesterday's Regatta :—
Class 1
Class II
Rating Class.
Corrected.
The wind was light from the N.W.
Although the Nanine was the winner in Class 1, the Minnie had the greatest number of points, therefore carrying off the monthly prize.
In Class 11 only two boats started, and unfortunately one of them, the Shamrock, crossed the line too soon, thereby disqualifying her, the monthly prize going to the Masr.

In the Rating Class the Ananké and Sana-Pareille hail an equal number of points each, and although the Sans Pareille beat the Ananké by 23 seconds, she was disqualified for some of the crew catching hold of the Ananké's boom when rounding the Gas Buoy, the monthly prize, which in each case consisted of a silver inkstand going to the Ananké.
